[[File:InterpersonalBridge.jpg|thumb|A bridge between two individuals who have no previous connection leads to intermingling.]] '''Intermingling''', or [[heterophily]], from a sociological perspective includes the various forms of interactions between individuals that go against a particular society's [[Norm (social)|cultural norms.]] These relationships stem from [[Interpersonal ties#Weak tie hypothesis|weak]] or [[absent ties]], which are contrary to [[Interpersonal ties#Strong ties hypothesis|strong ties]] and constitute of networks between individuals who know little or nothing about one another. Examples of intermingling can include networking, work-place romance, or cross-cultural dating.{{wiktionary}}
__TOC__
== Overview == Intermingling is the opposite of homophily and xenophobia but individuals tend to be less heterophilic and more homophilic- associating and bonding with individuals similar to themselves. Homophily is more prevalent than heterophily because the strength of all ties between any two people depend on the amount of time spent together, of mutual confiding, and of emotional intensity.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Granovetter|first=Mark|date=May 1973|title=The Strength of Weak Ties|url=|journal=American Journal of Sociology|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Homophilic relationships are perceived to be easier to build and maintain as individuals feel they have a great deal in common.
Pertaining to the diffusion of relationships, intermingling and heterophily are perceived to create more damage. Thus, since individuals practice homophily tend to be strongly connected and hold strong ties between their groups, when an individual is removed from the group information is still passed easily among those who remain. Contrarily, in sectors where there is intermingling and the group fabricates weak ties and bridges (individuals who connect two strangers) the removal of an individual from this group threatens the continuation of relationships between the others left in the group.<ref name=":2" />
== Networking == [[Personal network]]s and [[Business networking|business networks]] are the social circles individuals find themselves within that are made up of strong and weak ties. The goal of these networks is to exchange information, act upon new opportunities, and have personal gain from the relationship. Intermingling has been known to enhance individuals' networking practices as heterophily is said to make people more successful through them being able to receive new information from weak ties. This conclusion comes from the observation of those who are perceived to be privileged and unprivileged (based on race, class, and gender) and how much in comparison to the other each group intermingles thus creating weak ties. The unprivileged groups (i.e. women, minorities, and lower classes) tend to be in small cliques with a very limited amount of weak ties meaning that their access to new opportunities and information is also limited.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Giuffre|first=Katherine|last2=Paxton|first2=Pamela|date=July 1997|title=Building Social Networks|url=http://search.proquest.com/socabs/docview/223525952/fulltext/A752A4D55E134729PQ/1?accountid=10901|journal=Teaching Sociology|doi=|pmid=|access-date=May 4, 2016}}</ref> These groups have been known to only interact with each other causing information to be trapped within their own circle and no new information to enter into the circle. In [[Stanley Milgram|Stanley Milgram's]] [[Small-world experiment|Small World Problem]] this breach in the spread of new information is described as group inbreeding.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Milgram|first=Stanley|date=May 1967|title=Small World Problem|url=http://snap.stanford.edu/class/cs224w-readings/milgram67smallworld.pdf|journal=Psychology Today|doi=|pmid=|access-date=May 4, 2016}}</ref>
=== Relationship diffusion === According to [[Mark Granovetter]] in his work the Strength of Weak Ties, intermingling is necessary in gaining access to new opportunities and personal gain as weak ties increase an individuals exposure to new information. Additionally, Granovetter's work found that information diffuses (spreads) more quickly and further when the network is made up of weak ties and bridges (individuals who connect two strangers). This is benefiting to individuals as information usually contain information on employment, business opportunities, and new ventures.<ref name=":2" />
== In romantic relationships ==
Intermingling is a term sometimes used to refer to several different ideas regarding how people connect in [[love]] [[Exogamy|intermarriage]], [[cultural assimilation]], [[miscegenation]] (racial mixing). Note that the history of cultural exchange and inter-societal conflict has produced terms for "intermingling" concepts which are colored by various cultural and societal norms such as xenophobia and [[racism]].
=== Within the workplace === Intermingling in the workplace is considered and commonly called [[workplace romance]]. Intermingling within the workplace is considered a sexual attraction between two individuals who work within the same organization and the relationship is perceived within the eyes of a third party.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Anderson|first = Claire|last2 = Fisher|first2 = Caroline|date = 1 August 1991|title = Male-Female Relationships in the Workplace: Perceived Motivations in Office Romance|url =|journal = Sex Roles|volume = 25-25|issue = 3–4|pages = 163–180|doi =10.1007/BF00289852|pmid =|access-date =}}</ref> Workplace romance is deemed a form of intermingling because they are usually not approved or allowed by company officials leading it to be taboo dating practice.[[File:Triangular Theory of Love.gif|thumb|Triangular Theory of Love components]]The interactions that take place within the workplace are romantically charges as both individuals are voluntarily involved and the mingling that takes place is not forced or unwanted. Additionally the individuals are officially labeled as more than just co-workers once they act physically on their mutual romantic feelings for each other. This may come in the form of dating or casual sex.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last = Pierce|first = Charles|last2 = Byrne|first2 = Donn|date = January 1996|title = Attraction in organizations: a model of workplace romance|url =|journal = Journal of Organizational Behavior|doi =10.1002/(sici)1099-1379(199601)17:1<5::aid-job734>3.0.co;2-e|volume=17|pages=5–32}}</ref>
Confirmation of intermingling within the workplace context also must support Sternberg's [[triangular theory of love]] which states that loving relationships consist of three components; [[Intimate relationship|intimacy]] (which attracts the individuals to each other), [[Passion (emotion)|passion]] (which causes the need to express feelings through physical attention and sexual intercourse), and [[Promise|commitment]] (which leads to the individuals deciding to stick with each other).<ref name=":0" />
==== Types of workplace romances ====
Relationships formed within the workplace are one of three types; hierarchical, lateral, or couples without direct interaction in their job description.<ref name=":1" /> [[File:Bill og Melinda Gates 2009-06-03 (bilde 01).JPG|thumb|Bill and Melinda Gates]] Relationships that are hierarchal within the place of employment happen when the involved individuals do not hold the same power in the context of their work. One individual's job position is seen as subordinate when compared to their significant other's position within the same company.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Karl|first=Katherine|last2=Sutton|first2=Cynthia|date=Spring 2000|title=An examination of the perceived fairness of workplace romance|url=|journal=Journal of Business and Psychology|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Famous examples of hierarchal romances include [[Bill Gates]] (CEO of [[Microsoft]]) and [[Melinda Gates|Melinda French]] (previous Product Manager of Microsoft),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/melinda-gates-turned-down-bill-gates-first-date|title=Why Melinda Gates Turned Bill Gates Down When He First Asked Her Out|website=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2016-03-27}}</ref> [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]] (previous [[Associate attorney|Summer Associate]] at [[Sidley Austin|Sidley Austin - Chicago Branch]]) and [[Michelle Obama|Michelle Robinson]] (Barack's Summer Mentor/Advisor) ''see [[Michelle Obama#Family life|Obama - Family Life]]'', and the notorious romance between [[Bill Clinton|President Bill Clinton]] and [[Monica Lewinsky]] (White House Intern) see [[Lewinsky scandal]].
Relationships that are lateral within the workplace are formed when the involved individuals are seen as holding equally powerful positions in their job descriptions. Persons participating in a lateral workplace romance can not be seen as superior or subordinate to one another.<ref name=":1" />
Leaders of organizations favor lateral relationships more than hierarchal relationships even though neither are fully supported. The dynamics of hierarchal relationships within the work context can possibly lead to a higher number of claims of sexual harassment. The [[Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson]] case, which claimed that workplace romances are not excluded in the [[Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964]], established that employers are responsible for the actions executed to their employees by the power-holding leaders of the institution.<ref name=":1" />
Also, hierarchal relationships can lead to conflict as the subordinate individual begins to be viewed by their co-workers as more favored than their equals. This favor is symbolized through pay raises, promotions, transfers, work load discrepancies and it usually leads to co-workers envying one another or carrying feelings of inequality.<ref name=":1" />
Couples who work for the same institution but have no direct interaction during their tasks at work may be two individuals who work in different departments or different sites. This form of dating stirs even less suspicions of favoritism than lateral and hierarchical forms of dating.<ref name=":1" />

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} [[File:HMS VIGILANT MOD 45137620.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The United Kingdom relies on four [[Vanguard-class submarine|''Vanguard''-class submarines]] to provide its nuclear deterrent. At least one submarine is always armed and on active service, carrying up to 16 [[Trident II]] [[submarine-launched ballistic missile]]s. Each missile has a range of 7000 miles (11,000 km), and can carry 12 independently controlled warheads each capable of destroying a large city.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Brown move to cut UK nuclear subs |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8270092.stm |publisher= BBC News |date=23 September 2009 |accessdate=24 January 2011}}</ref> ]]
The '''letters of last resort''' are four identically worded handwritten letters from the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] to the commanding officers of the four British [[Vanguard-class submarine|ballistic missile submarines]]. They contain orders on what action to take in the event that an enemy nuclear strike has destroyed the [[Government of the United Kingdom|British government]] and has killed or otherwise incapacitated both the prime minister and the "second person" (normally a high-ranking member of [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|the Cabinet]]) whom the prime minister has designated to make a decision on how to act in the event of the prime minister's death. In the event that the orders were to be carried out, the action taken could be the last official act of [[Government of the United Kingdom|Her Majesty's Government]].<ref name="Taylor 2016">{{cite web | title=Every new British prime minister pens a handwritten ‘letter of last resort’ outlining nuclear retaliation | website=Washington Post | date=13 July 2016 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/07/13/every-new-british-prime-minister-pens-a-hand-written-letter-of-last-resort-outlining-nuclear-retaliaton/ | accessdate=13 July 2016 | last=Taylor | first=Adam}}</ref>
The letters are stored inside two nested safes in the control room of each submarine.<ref>{{Cite journal|last= Rosenbaum |first= Ron | authorlink= |author2= |date=January 2009 |title=The Letter of Last Resort |journal=Slate Magazine |volume= | issue = |pages= |id= |url= http://www.slate.com/id/2208219 |accessdate= 18 May 2009 |quote= In the control room of the sub, the Daily Mail reports, "there is a safe attached to a control room floor. Inside that, there is an inner safe. And inside that sits a letter. It is addressed to the submarine commander and it is from the Prime Minister.}}</ref> The letters are destroyed unopened after a prime minister leaves office, so their content remains known only to the prime minister who issued them.<ref>{{Cite journal|last= Rosenbaum |first= Ron | authorlink= |author2= |date=January 2009 |title=The Letter of Last Resort |journal=Slate Magazine |volume= | issue = |pages= |id= |url= http://www.slate.com/id/2208219 |accessdate= 18 March 2012 |quote= [E]very prime minister in recent years has written such a letter and ... letters that go unused (Tony Blair's for instance) are destroyed without being read.}}</ref>
==Process== The letters are written as soon as a new prime minister takes office, after being told by the [[Chief of the Defence Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Defence Staff]] "precisely what damage a [[Trident missile]] could cause".<ref name="Norton-Taylor 2016">{{cite web | last=Norton-Taylor | first=Richard | title=Theresa May's first job: decide on UK's nuclear response | website=the Guardian | date=11 July 2016 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/12/theresa-mays-first-job-decide-on-uks-nuclear-response | accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref> These are then delivered to the submarines, with the previous prime minister's letters being destroyed without being opened.<ref name="Bunkall 2016">{{cite web | last=Bunkall | first=Alistair | title=May To Be Handed Keys To Nuclear Red Button | website=Sky News | date=13 July 2016 | url=http://news.sky.com/story/may-to-be-handed-keys-to-nuclear-red-button-10499943 | accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref>
In the event of the deaths of both the prime minister and the designated alternative decision-maker as a result of a nuclear strike, the commander(s) of the nuclear submarine(s) (at any time at least one is on patrol) would use a series of checks to ascertain whether the letters of last resort will have to be opened.<ref>{{cite news|title=Theresa May’s grim first task: Preparing for nuclear armageddon|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/the-grim-task-awaiting-theresa-may-preparing-for-nuclear-armageddon-uk-prime-minister-british-defense-letter-of-last-resort/|accessdate=15 July 2016|work=Politico|date=15 July 2016}}</ref>
According to [[Peter Hennessy]]'s book ''The Secret State: Whitehall and the Cold War, 1945 to 1970'', the process by which a {{sclass-|Vanguard|submarine}} commander would determine if the British government continues to function includes, amongst other checks, establishing whether [[BBC Radio 4]] continues broadcasting.<ref>{{cite news|title=HMS Apocalypse: Deep in the Atlantic, a submarine waits on alert with nuclear missiles that would end the world...|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1090400/HMS-Apocalypse-Deep-Atlantic-submarine-waits-alert-nuclear-missiles-end-world--.html|accessdate=10 May 2012 | location=London|work=Daily Mail}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=September 2017}}
In 1983, the procedure for [[UK Polaris programme|Polaris]] submarines was to open the envelopes if there was an evident nuclear attack, or if all UK naval broadcasts had ceased for four hours.<ref>{{Citation| last= Goodall| first= David| publication-date=1 August 2013 | date= 26 May 1983| title= Arrangements for briefing a new Prime Minister in the event of a change of administration following the 1983 General Election| publisher = [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|TNA]])|id= [[Cabinet Office|CAB]] 196/124 |url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/details/C13497321?uri=C13497321|accessdate=5 September 2013|format= [[PDF]] }}</ref>
==Options== While the contents of these letters are secret, according to the December 2008 BBC Radio 4 documentary ''The Human Button'', there were four known options given to the prime minister to include in the letters. The prime minister instructs the submarine commander to:
* retaliate with [[nuclear weapon]]s; * not retaliate; * use his or her own judgement; or * place the submarine under an allied country's command, if possible. The documentary mentions Australia and the United States.
''[[The Guardian]]'' reported in 2016 that the options are said to include: "Put yourself under the command of the US, if it is still there", "Go to Australia", "Retaliate", or "Use your own judgement".<ref name="Norton-Taylor 2016" />
The actual option chosen remains known only to the writer of the letter, as they are destroyed unopened when a Prime Minister leaves office. In a debate prior to the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 general election]] the opposition leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]], a lifelong anti-nuclear weapons campaigner, stated that he would write the letters of last resort if elected but did not state what option he would choose, while also saying that any use of nuclear weapons would be a “disaster”.<ref>{{cite web | title=Lifelong anti-nuclear campaigner Jeremy Corbyn says he’ll issue orders to Trident commanders | website=Metro | date=29 May 2017 | url=https://metro.co.uk/2017/05/29/lifelong-anti-nuclear-campaigner-jeremy-corbyn-says-hell-issue-orders-to-trident-commanders-6670785/ | accessdate=20 Jun 2018 | last=Smith | first=Adam}}</ref>
==Fiction== [[David Greig (dramatist)|David Greig]]'s 2012 play ''The Letter of Last Resort'' deals with the consequences and paradoxes of the letters.<ref>[[David Greig (dramatist)|David Greig]], ''[http://www.front-step.co.uk/2015/09/30/letter-of-last-resort/ The Letter of Last Resort]'' (full text of play), front-step.co.uk (David Greig's official website), posted 30 September 2015.</ref>
The play was first staged in February 2012 as a part of a cycle of plays on "The Bomb" at the [[Tricycle Theatre]] in London, directed by [[Nicolas Kent]], with [[Belinda Lang]] playing the role of the incoming prime minister and [[Simon Chandler]] her advisor.<ref>[[Michael Billington (critic)|Michael Billington]], [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/feb/21/the-bomb-review The Bomb - review], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 February 2012</ref> The production was also seen at the [[Traverse Theatre]] in Edinburgh, for the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] later the same year.<ref>[http://www.tricycle.co.uk/home/about-the-tricycle-pages/about-us-tab-menu/archive/archived-theatre-production/the-letter-of-last-resort/ Edinburgh Transfer: The Letter of Last Resort], [[Tricycle Theatre]], August 2012</ref> The following year it was broadcast on [[BBC Radio 4]], with the same cast, first transmitted on 1 June 2013.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Saturday Drama, The Last Resort|work=BBC Radio 4 website|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0210spc|date=1 June 2013|accessdate=1 June 2013}}</ref>
The KGB's attempts to obtain the contents of the letters of last resort are part of the plot of the BBC [[Cold War]] spy drama ''[[The Game (UK TV series)|The Game]]'' (2014).<ref>{{cite news |last1=Frost |first1=Vicky |title=The Game recap: series one, episode two – Operation Glass is revealed |url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2015/may/07/the-game-recap-series-one-episode-two-operation-glass-is-revealed |accessdate=14 November 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=7 May 2015 |language=en}}</ref>

{{Infobox author bibliography | Author = William Gibson | Image = William Gibson by FredArmitage.jpg | ImageSize = 250px | Caption = William Gibson in 2007 | Novel = 11 | NovelLink = Novels | Article =25 | ArticleLink = Articles | Story =21 | StoryLink =Short fiction | Collection =1 | CollectionLink =Collected | Script = 6 | ScriptLink = Screenplays | References = Yes | RefLink = References | 1Option =13 | 1OptionName =Screen appearances | 1OptionLink =Screen appearances | 1OptionColor =turquoise | 2Option =16 | 2OptionName =Forewords, introductions and afterwords | 2OptionLink =Forewords, introductions and afterwords | 2OptionColor =#44EEAA | 3Option =9 | 3OptionName =Miscellanea | 3OptionLink =Miscellanea | 3OptionColor =#CCEE66 }} The works of [[William Gibson]] encompass literature, journalism, acting, recitation, and performance art. Primarily renowned as a novelist and short fiction writer in the [[cyberpunk]] milieu, Gibson invented the metaphor of [[cyberspace]] in "[[Burning Chrome]]" (1982) and emerged from obscurity in 1984 with the publication of his [[debut novel]] ''[[Neuromancer]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last= Prucher |first= Jeff |title= Brave New Words: The Oxford Dictionary of Science Fiction |publisher= Oxford University Press |year= 2007 |page= 31 |isbn= 978-0-19-530567-8 |oclc= 76074298 }}</ref><ref name="remembering">{{cite journal |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/3.06/gibson.html |title=Remembering Johnny: Notes on a process |accessdate=2008-01-10 |last=van Bakel |first=Rogier |journal=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=June 1995 | issue=3.06}}</ref> Gibson's early short fiction is recognized as cyberpunk's finest work,<ref name="storming">{{cite book | last = McCaffery | first = Larry | title = Storming the Reality Studio: a casebook of cyberpunk and postmodern science fiction | publisher = [[Duke University Press]] | location = [[Durham, North Carolina]] | year = 1991 | isbn = 978-0-8223-1168-3 | oclc = 23384573}}</ref> effectively renovating the [[science fiction]] genre which had been hitherto considered widely insignificant.<ref name="litencyc">{{cite web | last =Rapatzikou | first =Tatiani | title =William Gibson. | work =[[The Literary Encyclopedia]] | publisher =The Literary Dictionary Company | date =2003-06-17 | url =http://www.litencyc.com/php/speople.php?rec=true&UID=5198 | accessdate =2007-08-27}}</ref>
At the turn of the 1990s, after the completion of his [[Sprawl trilogy]] of novels, Gibson contributed the text to a number of performance art pieces and exhibitions,<ref name="remembering"/><ref name="architecture">{{cite news |first=Paul |last=Goldberger |title=In San Francisco, A Good Idea Falls With a Thud |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE1DB103CF931A2575BC0A966958260 |work=Architecture View |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=1990-08-12 |accessdate=2007-11-06 }}</ref><ref name=skier/> as well as writing lyrics for musicians [[Yellow Magic Orchestra]] and [[Debbie Harry]].<ref name=technodon/><ref name="debravation"/> He wrote the critically acclaimed artist's book ''[[Agrippa (a book of the dead)]]'' in 1992 before co-authoring ''[[The Difference Engine]]'', an alternate history novel that would become a central work of the [[steampunk]] genre.<ref name="steampunkt">{{cite news | first = Peter | last = Bebergal | title = The age of steampunk | url = http://www.boston.com/news/globe/ideas/articles/2007/08/26/the_age_of_steampunk/ | publisher = [[The Boston Globe]] | page = 3 | date = 2007-08-26 | accessdate = 2007-10-14}}</ref> He then spent an unfruitful period as a Hollywood [[screenwriter]], with few of his projects seeing the light of day and those that did being critically unsuccessful.<ref>[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/johnny_mnemonic/ Johnny Mnemonic] at [[Rotten Tomatoes]]. Retrieved 2008-01-15.</ref>
Although he had largely abandoned short fiction by the mid-1990s, Gibson returned to writing novels, completing his second trilogy, the [[Bridge trilogy]] at the close of the millennium. After writing two episodes of the television series ''[[The X-Files]]'' around this time, Gibson was featured as the subject of a documentary film, ''[[No Maps for These Territories]]'', in 2000.<ref name="nomaps">{{cite video |people=Mark Neale (director), William Gibson (subject) |title=[[No Maps for These Territories]] |publisher=Docurama |medium=Documentary |date=2000 }}</ref> Gibson has been invited to address the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] (1993) and the [[Directors Guild of America]] (2003) and has had a plethora of articles published in outlets such as ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and ''[[The New York Times]]''. His third trilogy of novels, ''[[Pattern Recognition (novel)|Pattern Recognition]]'' (2003), ''[[Spook Country]]'' (2007) and ''[[Zero History]]'' (2010) have put Gibson's work onto mainstream bestseller lists for the first time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20030510/ai_n12684401 |title=Books: Hardbacks |accessdate=2007-07-08 |last=Hirst |first=Christopher |date=2003-05-10 |publisher=[[The Independent]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013205201/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20030510/ai_n12684401 |archivedate=2007-10-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Novels == * [[Sprawl trilogy]]: *# ''[[Neuromancer]]'' (1984) *# ''[[Count Zero]]'' (1986) *# ''[[Mona Lisa Overdrive]]'' (1988) * ''[[The Difference Engine]]'' (1990; with [[Bruce Sterling]]) * [[Bridge trilogy]]: *# ''[[Virtual Light]]'' (1993) *# ''[[Idoru]]'' (1996) *# ''[[All Tomorrow's Parties (novel)|All Tomorrow's Parties]]'' (1999) [[File:No Altered Maps for Spook Country.jpg|thumb|right|Gibson discussing ''[[Spook Country]]'' (2007) on August 8, 2007 while touring in support of the novel.]] * Blue Ant trilogy: *# ''[[Pattern Recognition (novel)|Pattern Recognition]]'' (2003) *# ''[[Spook Country]]'' (2007) *# ''[[Zero History]]'' (2010) * ''[[The Peripheral]]'' (2014)

{{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = London lore : the legends and traditions of the world's most vibrant city | image = File:London Lore.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Steve Roud]] | audio_read_by = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = History and folklore of [[London]] | set_in = [[London]] | published = [[London]] | publisher = Arrow Books ([[Random House]]) | publisher2 = | pub_date = 2008 | media_type = Print (paperback) | pages = 438 | awards = | isbn = 9780099519867 | oclc = | dewey = 398.209421 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''London lore: the legends and traditions of the world's most vibrant city''''' is a 2008 book by [[Steve Roud]], concerning the [[folklore]] and history of [[London]]. Another edition was published in 2010.
==Background== The book presents various unique stories and traditions to come from historical London, such as [[Spring-heeled Jack]] and [[Pearly Kings and Queens]].
==Reception== In ''[[The Guardian]]'' Nicholas Lezard chose the book as a favourite and wrote ' it doesn't matter if you're reading this in London, Glasgow or Smolensk: you're going to find this an enthralling book. Assuming, that is, that you are interested in superstitions, magic, legends, history and the endless parade of human credulity'.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/apr/24/london-lore-legends-traditions-round</ref> [[Londonist]] described the book as 'an excellent tome'<ref>http://londonist.com/2008/10/book_review_london_lore_by_steve_ro.php</ref> while in the ''[[London Evening Standard]]'' [[Will Self]] wrote that he had been 'enthralled' by the book.<ref>https://www.standard.co.uk/standard-home/london-lore-the-legends-and-traditions-of-the-worlds-most-vibrant-city-by-steve-roud-6921589.html</ref> The book was also praised by historian [[Peter Ackroyd]], in the ''[[Camden New Journal]]'' as 'fascinating' and 'admirably put together'<ref>http://www.thecnj.com/review/2009/012909/books012909_01.html</ref> and 'a spellbinding study of our city's folklore' in the ''[[Newham Recorder]]''.

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} [[File:Museum Street corner 1104989 6a48d359.jpg|thumb|upright|The corner of [[Great Russell Street]] and Museum Street.]] [[File:Museum Street and New Oxford Street, Bloomsbury - geograph.org.uk - 603654.jpg|thumb|upright|Looking north along Museum Street, towards [[New Oxford Street]], with the [[Steeple (architecture)|steeple]] of [[St George's Church, Bloomsbury]] in the background.]]
'''Museum Street''' is a street in the [[Bloomsbury]] area of the [[London Borough of Camden]], [[England]]. To the north is the [[British Museum]], hence its current name. The street is populated by cafes and bookshops to appeal to the international [[museum]]-going public.<ref>[http://www.allinlondon.co.uk/regions/bloomsbury/museum-street.php Museum Street, Bloomsbury Shopping Guide], All In London.</ref><ref>[http://www.londononline.co.uk/area/Museum_Street_WC1A/ Shops on Museum Street, WC1A], LondonOnline.</ref> To the north is Great Russell Street. To the south are [[Bloomsbury Way]] and [[New Oxford Street]]. The nearest tube stations are [[Tottenham Court Road tube station|Tottenham Court Road]] and [[Holborn tube station|Holborn]] to the southwest and southeast respectively.<ref>[http://www.londontown.com/LondonStreets/museum_street_7df.html London guide to Museum Street, WC1A], LondonTown.com.</ref>
==History== The street goes back to the 14th century and beyond. It remained largely rural until the late 17th century when the growth of London caused its urbanisation.
Known as a thoroughfare since records began, it soon came to be known as ''Peter Street''. The origins of this name are unsure though scholars agree {{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} it is unlikely to have been an eminent Peter (notwithstanding perhaps St Peter) and more probable it derives from a [[Potassium nitrate|saltpetre]] manufactory which is thought to have existed there long before the British Museum opened in the 1750s. During the early years the street was the site of hovels of slum tenements and rather unsavoury characters such as pickpockets and prostitutes. An attempt at gentrification saw its name changed to ''Queen Street'' and it became home to parish schools to ensure the spiritual and secular education of poor children in London. Around this time [[Charles Mudie]] opened his bookshop and stationers here, he soon explored the possibility of lending books as well as selling them and ''Mudie's Select Library'' proved so popular that it moved out to larger premises after ten years. The street also became a rather fashionable area with many of the foremost writers of the day gathering in taverns to converse and debate. [[Charles Dickens]] drank here when he was dedicating his energy to amateur dramatics, [[John Keats]], [[George Orwell]] and the [[Bloomsbury Set]] were also patrons.
On the corner of Great Russell Street at the northern end is the Museum Tavern, a [[public house]] that traces its origins back to 1723.<ref>Henderson, John N. (1989). ''A history of the Museum Tavern in Bloomsbury''. London: Blemund's Books. {{ISBN|0-9514913-0-X}}.</ref> From 1723 to 1762 the pub was called the ''Dog and Duck'' (so called because duck hunting was popular in the ponds in the Long Fields behind [[Montagu House, Bloomsbury|Montagu House]] in the 17th and 18th centuries). The occult [[Atlantis Bookshop]] was opened on the street in 1922.
More recent history has seen the street set up as a paragon for pedestrian access. [[London Borough of Camden|Camden]]'s 2003, ''Car Free Day'' saw the streetscape give right of way to foot passengers — a success which was heralded across [[Europe]] as an example of best practice in cutting vehicular noise and pollution.
